div.p: MOTHER BOMBIE. As it was sundrie times plaied by the Children of Powles.
LONDON, Imprinted by Thomas Scarlet for Cuthbert Burby. 1594.

div.head: A pleasant conceited Comoedie, called Mother Bombie.

sp.speaker: Memphio.
sp.p: BOY, there are three thinges that make my life miserable, a threed bare purse, a curst wife, & a foole to my heire. Dromio. Why then sir, there are three medicines for these three malaladies: a pike-staffe to take a purse on the high way, a holy wand to brush cholar from my mistres tong, and a young wench for my yong master: so that as your Worship being wise begot a foole, so he beeing a foole may tread out a wise man.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: I but Dromio, these medicines bite hot on great mischiefs, for so might I haue a rope about my necke, hornes vpon my head, and in my house a litter of fooles.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p:
Then sir you had best let some wise man sit on your sonne, to hatch him a good wit: they saie,
if rauens sit on hens egs the chickens will be black, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Why boy, my sonne is out of the shell, and is growen a pretie cocke.

sp.speaker: Drom.
sp.p: Carue him master, & make him a capon, els all your breed will proue cockescombes.

sp.speaker: Memph.
sp.p: I maruell he is such an asse, hee takes it not of his father.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: He may for anie thing you know.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Why villain dost thou think me a foole?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: O no sir, neither are you sure that you are his father.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Rascall, doest thou imagine thy mistres naught of her bodie?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: No, but fantasticall of her mind, and it may be, when this boy was begotten shee thought of a foole, & so conceiued a foole, your selfe beeing verie wise, and she surpassing honest.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: It may be, for I haue heard of an Aethiopian, that thinking of a faire picture, brought forth a faire ladie, and yet no bastard.

sp.speaker: Drom.
sp.p: You are well read sir, your sonne may be a bastard and yet legitimate, your selfe a cuckold, & yet my mistres vertuous, all this in conceit.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Come Dromio, it is my grief to haue such a sonne that must inherit my lands.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: He needs not sir, Ile beg him for a foole.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Vile boy, thy yong master?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Let me haue in a deuice.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Ile haue thy aduice, and if it fadge, thou shalt eate, thou shalt sweate, play till thou sleep, and sleepe till thy bones ake.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: I marie, now you tickle me, I am both hungrie, gamesome, & sleepie, and all at once, Ile breake this head against the wal but Ile make it bleed good matter.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Then this it is, thou knowest I haue but one sonne, and he is a foole.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: A monstrous foole.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: A wife and she an arrand scold.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Ah master I smell your deuice, it will be excellent.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Thou canst not know it till I tell it.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: I see it through your braines, your haire is so thin, and your scull so transparant, I may sooner see it than heare it.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Then boy hast thou a quicke wit, and I a slow tongue, but what ist?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Marie either you would haue your wiues tong in your sons head, that he might bee a prating foole, or his braines in hir brain pan, that she might be a foolish scold.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Thou dreamst Dromio, there is no such matter, thou knowest I haue kept him close, so that my neighbors thinke him to be wise, and her to be temperate, because they neuer heard them speake.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Thou knowest that Stellio hath a good farme and a faire daughter, yea so faire, that she is mewed vp, and onely looketh out at the windows, least she should by some roisting courtier be stollen away.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: So sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p:
Now if I could compasse a match between my sonne and Stellios daughter by conference of
vs parents, and without theirs, I should be blessed, he coosned, and thou for euer set at libertie.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: A singular conceit.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Thus much for my sonne. Nowe for my wife, I would haue this kept from her, else shal I not be able to keepe my house from smoake, for let it come to one of her eares, & then wo to both mine: I would haue her goe to my house into the Countrie whilest we conclude this, and this once done, I care not if her tong neuer haue done: these if thou canst effect, thou shalt make thy master happie.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Thinke it done, this noddle shall coin such new deuice as you shall haue your sonne marryed py to morrow.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: But take heed, that neither the father nor the maide speak to my sonne, for then his folly will marre all.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Lay all the eare on mee, Subleuabo te onere, I will rid you of a foole.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Wilt thou rid me for a foole?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Tush, quarrell not.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Then for the dowrie, let it bee at least two hundreth ducats, and after his death the farme.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: What else?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Then let vs in, that I may furnish thee with some better counsell, and my sonne with better apparell.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Let me alone, I lacke but a wagge more to make of my counsell, and then you shall see an exquisite coosnage, & the father more foole than the sonne. But heare you sir, I forgot one thing.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Whats that?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Nay, Expellas furca licet vsque recurret.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Whats the meaning?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Why though your sons folly bee thrust vp with a paire of hornes on a forke, yet being naturall it will haue his course.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: I praie thee no more, but about it.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Risio, my daughter is passing amiable, but verie simple.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: You meane a foole sir.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Faith I implie so much.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Then I apply it fit: the one shee takes of her father, the other of her mother, now you may bee sure she is your owne.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: I haue penned her vp in a chamber, hauing onely a windowe to looke out, that youthes seeing her fayre cheekes, may be enamoured before they heare her fond speech. How likest thou this head?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: There is verie good workmanship in it, but the matter is but base, if the stuffe had bene as good as the mold, your daughter had bene as wise as she is beautifull

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Doest thou thinke she tooke her foolishnes of mee?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: I, & so cunningly, that she toke it not from you.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Well, Quod natura dedit tollere nemo potest.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: A good euidence to proue the fee-simple of your daughters folly.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: It came by nature, and if none can take it awaie, it is perpetuall.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Nay Riscio, she is no natural foole, but in this consisteth her simplicitie, that she thinketh herselfe selfe subtile in this her rudenesse, that she imagines she is courtly, in this the ouershooting of her selfe, that she ouerweeneth of her selfe.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Well, what followes?

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Risio this is my plot, Memphio hath a pretie stripling to his sonne, whom with cockring he hath made wanton, his girdle must be warmde, the ayre must not breath on him, he must lie a bed til noon, and yet in his bed breake his fast, that which I doe to conceale the folly of my daughter, that doth hee in too much cockering of his sonne. Now Risio how shall I compasse a match betweene my girle and his boy?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Why with a payre of compasses, and bring them both into the circle, He warrant the'il match themselues.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Tush, plot it for me, that neuer speaking one to another, they be in loue one with another, I like not solemne woing, it is for courtiers, let countrie folkes beleeue others reports as much as their own opinions.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: O then, so it be a match you care not.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Not I, nor for a match neither, were it not I thirst after my neighbors farme.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: A verie good nature. Well, if by flat wit I bring this to passe, whats my rewerd?

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Whatsoeuer thou wilt aske.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p:
Ile aske no more than by my wit I can get in
the bargaine.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Then about it.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: If I come not about you neuer trust mee, Ile seeke out Dromio, the counseller of my conceit.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: It is vnneighbourly done to suffer your son since hee came from schoole to spende his time in loue, and vnwisely done to let him houer ouer my daughter, who hath nothing to her dowrie but her needle, & must proue a Sempster, nor he any thing to take to but a Grammer, and cannot at the best be but a schoolemaster.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Prisius, you bite and whine, wring me on the withers, and yet winch your selfe, it is you that goe about to match my girle with my boy, shee beeing more fit for seames than for marriage, and hee for a rod than a wife.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Her birth requires a better bridegrome than such a groome.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: And his bringing vp another gate marriage than such a minion.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Marie gup, I am sure he hath no better bread than is made of wheat, nor worne finer cloth than is made of woll, nor learned better manners than are taught in schooles.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p:
Nor your minxe had no better grandfather than a Tailer, who (as I haue heard) was poore and proud: nor a better father than your selfe, vnlesse
your wife borrowed a better to make her daughter a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Twit not me with my ancestors, nor my wiues honestie, if thou doest.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Hold thy hands still thou hadst best, & yet it is impossible now I remember, for thou hast the palsy

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: My handes shake so, that wert thou in place where, I would teach thee to cog.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Nay, if thou shake thy hands, I warrant thou canst not teach anie to cog. But neighbour, let not two olde fooles fall out for two yong wantons.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Indeed it becommeth men of our experience to reason, not raile: to debate the matter, not to combat it.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Wel, then this Ile tel thee friendly, I haue almost these two yeres cast in my head, how I might match my princockes with Stellios daughter, whom I haue heard to be verie faire, and know shal be verie rich, she is his heire, he doats, he is stooping old, and shortly must die, yet by no meanes, either by blessing or cursing can I win my sonne to be a woer, which I know proceeds not of bashfulnesse but stubbornnesse, for hee knowes his good though I saie it, he hath wit at wil: as for his personage, I care not who sees him, I can tell you he is able to make a Ladies mouth water if she winke not.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p:
Stay Sperantus, this is like my case, for I haue bene tampering as long to haue a marriage committed betweene my wench and Memphios only son, they saie he is as goodly a youth as one shall see in a Summers daie, and as neate a stripling as euer went on neats leather, his father will not let him be forth
of his sight, he is so tender ouer him, he yet lies with his mother for catching cold. Now my pretie else, as proud as the day is long, she wil none of him, she forsooth wil choose her owne husband, made marriages proue mad marriages, shee will choose with her eie and like with her heart before she consent with her tong, neither father nor mother, kith nor kin shalbe her caruer in a husband, shee will fall too where she likes best, and thus the chicke scarce out of the shell cackles as though she had bene troden with an hundreth cockes, and mother of a thousand egges.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Well then this is our best, seeing we knowe each others minde, to deuise to gouerne our owne children, for my boy, Ile keepe him to his bookes, & studie shall make him leaue to loue, Ile breake him of his will or his bones with a cudgell.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: And Ile no more dandle my daughter, shee shall prick on a clout till her fingers ake, or Ile cause her leaue to make my heart ake. But in good time, though with ill lucke, beholde if they be not both together, let vs stand close and heare all, so shall we preuent all.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: This happens pat, take heed you cough not Prisius.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Tush spit not you, & Ile warrant I my beard is as good as a handkerchiefe.

sp.speaker: Liuia.
sp.p: Sweet Candius, if thy father should see vs alone, would be not fret? The old man me thinkes should be full of fumes.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p:
Tush, let him fret one heart string against another, he shal neuer trouble the least vaine of my
little finger, the old churle thinkes none wise, vnles he haue a beard hang dangling to his wast, when my face is bedaubed with haire as his, then perchance my conceit may stumble on his staiednes.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I, in what booke read you that lesson.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: I know not in what booke hee read it, but I am sure he was a knaue to learne it.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: I beleeue faire Liuia, if your soure fire shuld see you with your sweet heart, he would not be verie patient.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: The care is taken, Ile aske him blessing as a father, but neuer take counsel for an husband, there is as much oddes between my golden thoughts, & his leaden aduice, as betweene his siluer haires and my amber lockes, I know hee will cough for anger that I yeeld not, but he shall cough mee a foole for his labour.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Where pickt your daughter that worke, out of broad-stitch?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Out of a flirts sampler, but let vs stay the end, this is but the beginning, you shall heare two children well brought vp.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Parents in these daies are growen pieuish, they rocke their children in their cradles till they sleepe, and crosse them about their bridals till their hearts ake. Marriage among them is become a market, what will you giue with your daughter? What Ioynter will you make for your sonne? And many a match is broken off for a penie more or lesse, as though they could not afford their children at such a price, when none should cheapen such ware, but affection, and none buy it but loue.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Learnedly and scholerlike.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: In deed our parents take great care to make vs aske blessing and say grace when as we are lyttle ones, and growing to yeeres of iudgement they depriue vs of the greatest blessing, and the most gracious things to our mindes, the libertie of our minds: they giue vs pap with a spoon before we can speak, and when wee speake for that wee loue, pap with a hatchet: because their fansies beeing growen musty with hoarie age, therefore nothing can relish in their thoughtes that sauours of sweet youth: they studie twentie yeeres together to make vs grow as straight as a wande, and in the ende by bowing vs make vs as crooked as a cammocke. For mine owne part (sweet Candius) they shall pardon me, for I will measure my loue by min owne iudgement, not my fathers purse or peeuishnes. Nature hath made me his child, not his slaue, I hare Memphio and his son deadly, if I wist he would place his affection by his fathers appointment.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Wittily but vnciuily.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Be of that minde still my faire Liuia, let our fathers lay their purses together, we our harts, I wil neuer woo where I cannot loue, let Stellio inioy his daughter. But what haue you wrought here?

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p:
Flowers, fowles, beasts, fishes, trees, plants, stones, and what not. Among flowers, cowslops & lillyes for our names Candius and Liuia. Among fowles, Turtles and Sparrowes, for our truth and desires. Among beasts, the foxe and the Ermin for beautie and policie, and among fishes the cockle & the Tortuse, because of Venus among trees, the
vine wreathing about the elme for our embracings. Among stones Abestor, which being hot wil neuer be colde, for our constancies. Among plants, Time and harts-ease, to note that if we take time we shall ease our hearts.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Theres a girle that knowes her lerripoope.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Listen & you shall heare my sons learning.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: What booke is that?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: A fine pleasant poet, who entreateth of the arte of Loue, and of the remedie.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: Is there arte in loue?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: A short art & a certain, three rules in 3. lines.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: I praie thee repeat them.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Principio quod amare velis reperire labora, Proximus huic labor est placidam euor are puellam, Tertius vt longo tempore ducet amor.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: I am no Latinist Cand. you must conster it.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: So I will and pace it too: thou shalt be acquainted with case, gender, and number. First one must finde out a mistres, whom before all others he voweth to serue. Secondly, that he vse al the means that he may to obtaine her. And the last with deserts, faith and secrecie to studie to keepe her.

sp.speaker: Liu:
sp.p: Whats the remedie?

sp.speaker: Can:
sp.p: Death.

sp.speaker: Liu:
sp.p: What of all the booke is the conclusion?

sp.speaker: Can:
sp.p: This one verse, Non caret essertu quod voluere duo.

sp.speaker: Liu:
sp.p: Whats that?

sp.speaker: Can:
sp.p: Where two are agreed, it is impossible but they must speed.

sp.speaker: Liu:
sp.p:
Then cannot we misse, therefore giue mee
thy hand Candius.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Soft Liuia, take mee with you, it is not good in lawe without witnes.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: And as I remember there must be two witnesses, God giue you ioy Candius, I was worth the bidding to dinner, though not worthy to be of the counsell.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I thinke this hot loue hath prouided but cold cheere.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Tush, in loue is no lacke, but blush not Candius, you neede not bee ashamed of your cunning, you haue made loue a booke case, and spent your time well at schoole, learning to loue by arte, and hate against nature, but I perceiue, the worser child the better louer.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p:
And my minion hath wrought well, where euery stitch in her sampler is a pricking stitch at my heart: you take your pleasure on parents, they are peeuish, fooles, churles, ouergrowen with ignorance, because ouerworne with age, litle shalt thou know the case of a father before thy selfe be a mother, when thou shalt breed thy childe with continuall paines, and bringing it foorth with deadly pangs, nurse it with thine owne paps, and nourish it vp with motherly tendernes, and then finde them to curse thee with their hearts, when they shoulde aske blessing on their knees, and the collop of thine owne bowels to be the torture of thine owne soul, with teares trickling downe thy checkes, and drops of bloud falling from thy heart, thou wilt in vttering of thy minde wish them rather vnborne than vnnatural, & to haue had their cradles their graues
rather than thy death their bridals. But I will not dispute what thou shouldst haue done, but correct what thou hast done, I perceiue sowing is an idle exercise, and that euerie daie there come more thoughtes into thine head, than stitches into thy worke, Ile see whether you can spin a better mind than you haue stitched, and if I coope you not vp, then let me be the capon.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: As for you sir boy, in stead of poaring on a booke, you shall holde the plough, Ile make repentance reape what wantonnesse hath sowen, but we are both well serued, the sonnes must bee masters, the fathers gaffers, what wee get together with a rake, they cast abroade with a forke, and wee must wearie our legges to purchase our children armes. Well, seeing that booking is but idlenesse, Ile see whether threshing be anie occupation, thy minde shall stoope to my fortune, or mine shall break the lawes of nature. How like a micher he standes, as though he had trewanted from honestie, get thee in, and for the rest let me alone. In villaine.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: And you pretie minx, that must be fed with loue vpon sops, Ile take an order to cram you with sorrowes, get you in without looke or reply.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Let vs follow, and deale as rigorously with yours as I will with mine, and you shall see that hot loue wil wax soone colde, Ile tame the proud boy, and send him as far from his loue as hee is from his duetie.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p:
Let vs about it, and also go on with matching them to our mindes, it was happie that we preuented
that by chance, which we could neuer yet suspect by circumstance.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Now if I could meete with Risio, it were a world of waggery.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Oh that it were my chance Obuiam dare Dromio, to stumble vpon Dromio, on whome I doo nothing but dreame.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: His knauerie and my wit should make our masters that are wise fooles, their children that are fooles beggers, and vs two that are bond free.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: He to cosin, & I to coniure, would make such alterations, that our masters shuld serue themselues, the ideots their children serue vs, and we to wake our wits betweene them all.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Hem quàm opportune, looke if he drop not ful in my dish.

sp.speaker: Risio.
sp.p: Lupus in fabula, Dromio imbrace me, hugge me, kisse my hand, I must make thee fortunate.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Risio, honor me, kneele downe to mee, kisse my feet, I must make thee blessed.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: My master olde Stellio hath a foole to his daughter.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Nay my master olde Memphio hath a foole to his sonne.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: I must conuey a contract.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: And I must conuey a contract.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p:
Betweene her and Memphios sonne, without
speaking one to another.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Betweene him and Stellios daughter without one speaking to the other.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Doest thou mocke me Dromio?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Thou doest me else.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Not I for all this is true.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: And all this.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Then are we both driuen to our wits endes, for if either of them had bin wise, wee might haue tempered, if no marriage, yet a close marriage.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Well, let vs sharpen our accounts, ther's no better grindstone for a young mans head; than to haue it whet vppon an olde mans purse. Oh thou shalt see my knauerie shaue lyke a rasor!

sp.speaker: Ris.
sp.p: Thou for the edge, and I the point wil make the foole bestride our mistres backs, and then haue at the bagge with the dudgin hafte, that is, at the dudgen dagger, by which hanges his tantonie pouch.

sp.speaker: Drom.
sp.p: These old huddles haue such strong purses with locks, when they shut them they go off like a snaphance.

sp.speaker: Ris.
sp.p: The olde fashion is best, a purse with a ring round about it, as a circle to course a knaues hande from it: but Dromio, two they saie may keep counsell is one be awaie: but to conuey knauerie, two are too few, and foure too many.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: And in good time, looke where Halfepenie Sperantus boy commeth, though bound vp in decimo sexto for carriage, yet a wit in folio for coosnage: Single Halfepenie, what newes are now currant?

sp.speaker: Halfepenie.
sp.p: Nothing but that such double coystrels as you be are counterfeit?

sp.speaker: Ris.
sp.p: Are you so dapper, weele sende you for an Halfepenie loafe.

sp.speaker: Halfepen.
sp.p: I shall goe for siluer though, when you you shall be nailed vp for slips.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Thou art a slipstring Ile warrant.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: I hope you shall neuer slip string, but hang steddie.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Dromio looke heere, now is my hand on my halfepenie.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Thou lyest, thou hast not a farthing to laie thy hands on, I am none of thine: but let mee bee wagging, my head is full of hammers, & they haue so maletted my wit, that I am almost a malcontent.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Why, whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: My master hath a fine scholer to his sonne, Prisius a fayre lasse to his daughter.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Half
sp.p: They two loue one another deadly.

sp.speaker: Ris.
sp.p: In good time.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: The feathers haue put them vp, vtterly disliking the match, and haue appointed the one shall haue Memphios sonne, the other Stellios daughter, this workes lyke waxe, but how it will fadge in the end, the hen that sits next the cocke cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Ris.
sp.p: If thou haue but anie spice of knauery wele make thee happie.

sp.speaker: Halfe.
sp.p: Tush, doubt not of mine, I am as full for my pitch as you are for yours, a wrens egge is as ful of meat as a goose eg, though there be not so much in it: you shal find this head wel stuft, though there went little stuffe to it.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Laudo ingenium, I lyke thy sconce, then harken: Memphio made me of his counsell about marriage of his sonne to Stellios daughter, Stellio made Riscio acquainted to plot a match with Memphios sonne. To be short, they be both fooles.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: But they are not fooles that bee short, if I thought thou meantst so, Senties qui vir sim, Thou shouldst haue a crow to pull.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Be not angrie Halfepenie, for fellowship we will be all fooles, and for gaine all knaues. But why doest thou laugh?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: At mine owne conceit and quicke censure.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Sodainly me thought you two were asses, and that the least asse was the more asse.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Thou art a foole, that cannot be.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Yea, my yong master taught me to proue it by learning, and so I can out of Ouid by a verse.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Prethee how?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: You must first for fashion sake confes your selues to be asses.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Then stand you here and you there.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Go to.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Then this is the verse as I point it, Cum mala per longas inualuêre moras. So you see the least asse is the more asse.

sp.speaker: Ris.
sp.p: Weele bite thee for an ape if thou bob vs lyke asses. But to end all, if thou wilt ioyne with vs, we will make a match betweene the two fooles, for that must be our tasks, and thou shalt deuise to couple Candius & Liuia, by ouer-reaching their fathers.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Let me alone, Non enim mea pigra iuuentus, there's matter in this noddle.
But looke where Prisius boy comes, as fit as a pudding for a dogs mouth.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: Pop three knaues in a sheath, Ile make it a right Tunbridge case, and be the bodkin.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Nay the bodkin is heere alreadie, you must be the knife.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: I am the bodkin, looke well to your eares, I must boare them.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Mew thy tongue or weele cut it out, this I speake representing the person of a knife, as thou didst that in shadow of a bodkin.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: I must begone, Taedet, it irketh, Oportet, it behoueth my wits worke like barme, alias yest, alias sizing, alias rising, alias Gods good.

sp.speaker: Hal.
sp.p: The new wine is in thine head, yet was hee faine to take this metaphor from ale, and now you talke of ale, let vs all to the wine.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Foure makes a messe, and we haue a messe of masters that must be cosned, let vs lay our heads together, they are married and cannot.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p:
Let vs consult at the Tauerne, where after to the health of Memphio, drinke we to the life of Stellio, I carouse to Prisius, & brinch you mas Sperantus, we shall cast vs our accounts and discharge
our stomackes, like men that can disgest any thing.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I see not yet what you go about.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Lucio that can pearce a mud wall of twentie foote thicke, would make vs beleeue he cannot see a candle through a paper lanthorne, his knauerie is beyond Ela, & yet he sayes he knowes not Gamvt.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I am readie, if anie cosnage be ripe, Ile shake the tree.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Nay, I hope to see thee so strong, to shake three trees at once.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: We burne time, for I must giue a reckning of my dayes worke, let vs close to the bush ad deliberandum.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: In deede Inter pocula philosophundum, it is good to plea among pots.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Thine will be the worst, I feare we shall leaue a halfepenie in hand.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Why, sayest thou that thou hast left a print deeper in thy hand alreadie than a halfpenie canne leaue, vnles it should sing worse than an hot yron.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: All friendes, and so let vs sing tis a pleasant thing to goe into the tauerne, cleering the throate.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Then seale vs for thy iolly Skinckers.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.l: How do'st thou the Nowle refine!

sp.speaker: Ris.
sp.l: Plump thou mak'st mens Rubie faces,
And from Girles canst fetch embraces;

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O the deare bloud of Grapes,
Now to shew trickes like Apes.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Make vs of thy Reeling Rabble.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: I maruell I heare no newes of Dromio, either he slackes the matter, or betrayes his master, I dare not motion anie thing to Stellio till I knowe what my boy hath don; Ile hunt him out; if the loitersacke be gone springing into a tauerne, Ile fetch him reeling out.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Without doubt Risio hath gone beyond himselfe, in casting beyond the Moone, I feare the boy be runne mad with studying, for I know hee loued me so well, that for my fauour hee will venture to runne out of his wits, and it may be, to quicken his inuention, hee is gone into this Iuy-bush, a notable neast for a grape owle, Ile firret him out, yet in the end vse him friendly, I cannot be merrie till I heare whats done in the marriages.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I thinke Lucio be gone a squirelling, but Ile squirell him for it, I sent him on my arrande, but I must goe for an answere myselfe, I haue tied vp the louing worme my daughter, and will see whether fansie can worme fansie out of her head, this green nosegaie I feare my boy hath smelt to, for if he get but a penny in his purse, he turnes it sodainly into Argentum potabile, I must search euery place for him, for I stand on thornes till I heare what he hath done.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p:
Well, be as bee may is no banning, I thinke I haue charmde my yong master, a hungry meale, a ragged coate, & a drie cudgell, haue put him quite beside his loue and his logick to, besides his pigsnie is put vp, & therefore now Ile let him take the aire, and follow Stellios daughter with all his learning, if he meane to be my heire, the boye hath wit sance measure, more than needs, cats meat & dogs meate inough for the vantage. Well, without Halfepenie all my witte is not woorth a dodkin, that mite
is miching in this groue, for as long as his name is Halfepenie, he will bee banquetting, for thether Halfepenie.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: He must needs goe that the deuill driues, a father, a fiend, that seekes to place affection by appointment, & to force loue by compulsion, I haue sworne to woo Sylena, but it shall be so coldly, that she shall take as small delight in my wordes, as I do contentment in his commandement, Ile teach him one schoole tricke in loue. But behold who is that that commeth out of Stellios house, it should seem to be Silena by her attire, Enter Silena .by her face I am sure it is she, oh faire face, oh louely countenance! How now Candius, if thou begin to slip at beautie on a sodaine, thou wilt surfet with carousing it at the last. Remember that Liuia is faithfull, I, and let thine eyes witnesse Silena is amiable, heere shall I please my father and my selfe, I wyll learne to be obedient, & come what will, Ile make away, if shee seeme coy, Ile practise all the arte of loue; if I her cunning, all the pleasures of loue.

sp.speaker: Sile.
sp.p:
My name is Silena I care not who knowe it, so I doo not: my father keeps me close, so he does, and now I haue stolne out, so I haue, to goe to olde Mother Bombie to know my fortune, so I wil, for I haue as fayre a face as euer trode on shoo sole, and
as free a foote as euer lookt with two eyes.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: What, I thinke she is lunatike or foolish? Thou art a foole Candius, so faire a face cannot bee the scabbard of a foolish minde, mad she may bee, for commonly in beautie so rare, there fals passions extreame, Loue and beautie disdaine a meane, not therefore because beautie is no vertue, but because it is happines, and we schollers know that vertue is not to be praised, but honored. I wil put on my best grace, sweete wench thy face is louely, thy bodie comely, & all that the eyes can see inchanting, you see how vnacquainted I am bold to boord you.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: My father boordes mee alreadie, therefore I care not if your name were Geoffrey.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: She raues or ouer-reaches. I am one sweet soule that loues you, brought hether by reporte of your beautie, and here languisheth with your rarenesse.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I thanke you that you would call.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: I will alwaies call on such a saint, that hath power to release my sorrowes, yeeld fayre creature to loue.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.p: I am none of that sect.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: The louing sect is an auncient sect and an honorable, and therefore should bee in a person so perfect.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Much.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: I loue thee much, giue mee one worde of comfort.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I faith sir no, and so tell your master.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: I haue no master, but come to make choise of a mistres.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Aha, are you there with your beares.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Doubtles she is an idiot of the newest cut, Ile once more trye hir. I haue loued thee long Silena.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: In your tother hose.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Too simple to be naturall: too senslesse to be arteficiall. You sayd you went to know your fortune, I am a scholler and am cunning in palmistry.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: The better for you sir, heres my hand, whats a clocke.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: The line of life is good, Venus mount very perfect, you shall haue a scholler to your first husband.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: you are well seene in carnes durt, your father was a poulter, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Why laugh you?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Because you should see my teeth.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Alas poore wench, I see now also thy folly, a fayre foole is lyke a fresh weed, pleasing leaues and soure iuyce. I will not yet leaue her, shee may dissemble. I cannot choose but loue thee.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I had thought to aske you.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Nay then farewell, either to proud to accept, or too simple to vnderstand.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: You need not bee so crustie, you are not so hard backt.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p:
Now I perceiue thy folly, who hath rakt together all the odde blinde phrases, that helpe them that knowe not howe to discourse, but when they cannot aunswere wisely, eyther with gybing couer theyr rudenesse, or by some newe coyned
buy worde bewraie theyr peeuishnesse, I am glad of this, nowe shall I haue coulour to refuse the match, and my father reason to accept of Liuia, I will home, and repeate to my father oure wise incounter, and hee shall perceiue there is nothing so fulsome as a shee foole.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: Good God, I thinke Gentlemen had neuer lesse wit in a yeere. Wee maides are madde wenches, we gird them and flout them out of all scotch and notch, and they cannot see it, I will knowe of the olde woman whether I bee a maide or no, and then if I bee not, I must needes be a man, God be heere.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: Whos's there.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: One that would be a maide.

sp.speaker: Bom:
sp.p: If thou be not, it is impossible thou shuldst be, and a shame thou art not.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: They saie you are a witch.

sp.speaker: Bomb:
sp.p: They lie, I am a cunning woman.

sp.speaker: Sil:
sp.p: Then tell mee some thing.

sp.speaker: Bomb:
sp.p: Holde vp thy hande, not so high, thy father knowes thee not, thy mother bare thee not, falsely bred, truely begot, choise of two husbands, but neuer tyed in bandes, because of loue and naturall bondes.

sp.speaker: Silena:
sp.p:
I thanke you for nothing, because I vnderstand nothing: though you bee as olde as you are, yet am I as younge as I am, and because that I am so fayre, therefore are you so fowle,
& so farewell frost, my fortune naught me cost.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: Farewell faire foole, little doest thou know thy hard fortune, but in the end thou shalt, & that must bewraie what none can discouer, in the mean season I wil professe cunning for all commers.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: We were all taken tardie.

sp.speaker: Ris.
sp.p: Our masters will be ouertaken if they tarry.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Now must euerie one by wit make an excuse, and euerie excuse must be coosnage.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Let vs remember our complot.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: We will all plod on that, oh the wine hath turnd my wit to vineger.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: You meane tis sharpe.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Sharpe? Ile warrant twill serue for as good sauce to knauerie as

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: As what?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: As thy knauerie meat for his wit.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: We must all giue a reckning for our dayes trauell.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Tush, I am glad we scapt the reckning for our liquor. If you be examined how we met, sweare by chance, for so they met, and therefore will beleeue it: if how much we drunke, let them answere them selues, they know best because they paid it.

sp.speaker: Hal.
sp.p: We must not tarry, abeundum est mihi, I must go and cast this matter in a corner.
I presequar a bowle, and Ile come after with a broome, euerie one remember his que.

sp.speaker: Ris.
sp.p: I and his k. or else we shall thriue ill.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: When shall we meete.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: To morrow fresh and fasting.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Fast eating our meate, for we haue drunke for to morow, & to morow we must eat for to day.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Away, away, if our masters take vs here the matter is mard.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Let vs euerie one to his taske.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: How luckily we met on a sodaine in a tauerne, that drunke not together almost these thirtie yeeres.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: A tauerne is the Randeuous, the Exchange, the staple for good fellowes, I haue heard my great grandfather tell how his great grandfather shoulde saie, that it was an olde prouerbe when his greate grandfather was a childe, that it was a good winde that blew a man to the wine.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: The olde time was a good time, Ale was an ancient drinke, and accounted of our ancestors autentical, Gascone wine was liquor for a Lord, Sack a medicine for the sicke, and I may tell you, he that had a cup of red wine to his oysters, was hoysted in the Queenes subsidie booke.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: I but now you see to what loosenes this age is growen; our boies carouse sack like double beere, and saith that which doth an old man good, can do a yong man no harme: old men (say they) eat pap, why shoulde not children drinke sacke, their white heads haue cosned time out of mind our yong yeres

sp.speaker: Memph:
sp.p: Well, the world is wanton since I knew it first, our boyes put as much nowe in their bellies in an houre, as would cloath theyr whole bodies in a yeere, wee haue paide for their tipling eight shillinges, and as I haue hearde, it was as much as bought Rufus, sometime king of this land, a paire of hose.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Ist possible.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Nay tis true; they saie, Ale is out of request, tis hogges porredge, broth for beggers, a caudle for cunstables, watchmens mouth glew; the better it is the more like bird lime it is; and neuer makes one staid but in the stockes.

sp.speaker: Memph:
sp.p: Ile teach my wag-halter to know grapes from barley.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: And I mine to discerne a spigot from a faucet.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: And I mine, to iudge the difference between a blacke boule and a siluer goblet.

sp.speaker: Stel:
sp.p: And mine shall learne the oddes betweene a stand and a hogs-head, yet I cannot choose but laugh to see how my wag aunswered mee, when I stroke him for drinking sacke.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Why what sayd he?

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p:
Master, it is the soueraigntest drinke in the world, and the safest for all times and weathers, if it thunder, though all the Ale and Beere in the towne turne, it will be constant; if it lighten, and that any fire come to it, it is the aptest wine to burn and the most wholesomest when it is burnt. So much for Summer. If it freeze, why it is so hot in operation, that no Ise can congeale it, if it rayne,
why then he that cannot abide the heate of it, may put in water. So much for winter. And so ranne his way, but Ile ouertake him.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Who woulde thinke that my hoppe on my thumbe, Halfpenie, scarse so high as a pint pot, wold reason the matter; but hee learnde his leere of my sonne, his young master, whom I haue brought vp at Oxford, and I thinke must learne heere in Kent at Ashford.

sp.speaker: Memph.
sp.p: Why what sayd he?

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Hee boldly rapt it out, Sine Cere & Baccho friget Venus, without wine and sugar his veins wold waxe colde.

sp.speaker: Memph.
sp.p: They were all in a pleasant vaine, but I must be gone, and take account of my boyes businesse, farewell neighbours, God knowes when we shall meete againe, yet I haue discouered nothing, my wine hath beene my wittes friende, I longe to heare what Dromio hath done.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: I cannot staie, but this good fellowshippe shall cost mee the setting on at our next meeting, I am gladde I blabd nothing of the marriage, now I hope to compas it, I know my boy hath bin bungling about it.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Let vs all goe, for I must to my clothes that hang on the tenters, my boy shall hang with them, if hee aunswere mee not his dayes worke.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p:
If all bee gone Ile not staie, Halfepenie I am sure hath done mee a pennie woorth of good,
else Ile spend his bodie in buying a rod.

sp.speaker: Maest.
sp.p: Sweet sister, I know not how it commeth to passe, but I finde in my selfe passions more than brotherly.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: And I deare brother finde my thoughts intangled with affections beyonde nature, which so flame into my distempered head, that I can neither without danger smother the fire, nor without modestie disclose my furie.

sp.speaker: Maest.
sp.p: Our parents are pore, our loue vnnaturall, what can then happen to make vs happie?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Onely to be content with our fathers mean estate, to combat against our own intemperate desires, and yeld to the succes of fortune, who though she hath framd vs miserable, cannot make vs monstrous.

sp.speaker: Maest.
sp.p: It is good counsel faire sister, if the necessitie of loue could be releeued by counsell, yet this is our comfort, that these vnnaturall heates haue stretched themselues no further than thoughts, vnhappie me that they should stretch so.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: That which nature warranteth laws forbid, straunge it seemeth in sense, that because thou art mine, therefore thou must not be mine.

sp.speaker: Maest.
sp.p: So it is Serena, the neerer we are in bloud, the further wee must be from loue, and the greater the kindred is, the lesse the kindnes must be, so that between brothers & sisters superstition hath made affection cold, between strangers custome hath bred loue exquisite.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: They say there is hard by an old cunning woman, who can tell fortunes, expound dreames, tell of things that be lost, and deuine of accidents to come, she is called the good woman, who yet neuer did hurt.

sp.speaker: Maest.
sp.p: Nor anie good I thinke Serena, yet to satisfie thy minde we will see what she can saie.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Good brother let vs.

sp.speaker: Maest.
sp.p: who is within?

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: The dame of the house?

sp.speaker: Maest.
sp.p: She might haue said the beldam, for her face and yeeres, and attire.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Good mother tell vs, if by your cunning you can, what shall become of my brother and me.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: Let me see your hands, and looke on me stedfastly with your eyes. You shall be married to morow hand in hand, by the lawes of good nature & the land, your parents shall be glad, & giue you their lande, you shal each of you displace a foole, & both together must releeue a foole. If this be not true call me olde foole.

sp.speaker: Maest.
sp.p: This is my sister, marrie we cannot: our parents are poore and haue no land to giue vs, each of vs is a foole to come for counsell to such an olde foole.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: These doggrell rimes and obscure words, comming out of the mouth of such a weather-beaten witch, are thought diuinations of some holy spirite, being but dreames of decayed braines; for mine owne parte, I would thou mightest sit on that stoole till he & I marrie by lawe.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: I saie Mother Bombie neuer speakes but once, and yet neuer spake vntruth once.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Come brother, let vs to our poore home, this is our comfort, to bewraie our passions, since we cannot inioy our loue.

sp.speaker: Maest.
sp.p: Content sweet sister, and learne of me hereafter, that these olde sawes of such olde hags, are but false fires to leade one out of a plaine path into a deepe pit.

div.head: Act, 3. Sce. 2.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Ingenium quondam fuerat pretiotius auro, the time was wherein wit would worke like waxe, and crock vp golde like honnie.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: At nunc barbarie est grandis habere nihil, but nowe wit and honestie buy nothing in the market.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: What Risio, how spedst thou after thy potting?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Nay, my master rong all in the tauerne, & thrust all out in the house. But how spedst thou?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: I, it were a dayes worke to discourse it, he spake nothing but sentences, but they were vengible long ones, for when one word was out, hee made pause of a quarter long till he spake another.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Why what did he in all that time?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Breake interiections lyke winde, as eho, ho, to.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: And what thou?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Aunswere him in his owne language, as euax, vah, hui.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: These were coniunctions rather than interiections. But what of the plot?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: As we concluded I tolde him that I vnderstood that Silena was verie wise, and could sing exceedingly, that my deuise was, seeing Accius his sonne a proper youth, & could also sing sweetly, that he should come in the nicke when she was singing and answere her.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p:
Then hee asked how it should be deuised that she might come abroade, I tolde that was cast alreadie
by my meanes, then the song beeing ended, and they seeing one another, noting the apparell, and marking the personages, he should call in his sonne for feare he should ouer-reach his speech.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Then that I had gotten a young Gentleman that resembled his sonne in yeeres and fauour, that hauing Accius apparell should court Silena, whome shee finding wise, would after that by small intreatie be won without mo wordes, & so the marriage clapt vp by this cosnage, and his sonne neuer speake word for himselfe.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Thou boy, so haue I done in euerie point, for the song, the calling her in, & the hoping that another shall woo Accius, and his daughter wed him, I told him this wooing should be to night, and they early marryed in the morning, without anie wordes sauing to saie after the Priest.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: All this fodges well; now if Halfpenie and Luceo haue playde theyr partes, wee shall haue exccellent sporte, and here they come. Howe wrought the wine my lads?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: How? like wine, for my bodie being the rundlet, and my mouth the vent, it wrought two daies ouer, till I had thought the hoopes of my head woulde haue flowen asunder.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: The best was, our masters were as well whitled as we, for yet they lie by it.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: The better for vs, we dyd but a little parboile our liuers, they haue sod theyrs in sacke these fortie yeeres.

sp.speaker: Hal.
sp.p: That makes them spit white broth as they doo. But to the purpose. Candius and Liuia will send their attires, you must send the apparell of Accius and Silena, they wonder wherefore, but commit the matter to our quadrapertit wit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If you keepe promise to marrie them by your deuice, and their parents consent, you shall haue tenne pounds a peece for your paines.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: If wee doo it not wee are vndone, for we haue broacht a cosnage alreadie, and my master hath the tap in his hand, that it must needs runne out, let them he ruld and bring hether their apparell, and we wil determine, the rest commit to our intricate considerations, depart.

div.stage: Exeunt Halfepenie, Luceo. Enter Accius and Silena.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Here comes Accius tuning his pipes, I perceiue my master keepes touch.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: And here comes Silena with her wit of proofe▪ marie it will scarse holde out question shot, let vs in to instruct our masters in the que.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Come let vs be iogging, but wert not a world to heare them woe one another.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: That shall be hereafter to make vs sport, but our masters shall neuer know it.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.l: Wherefore hast thou feete and wings?
It is to shew how swift thou art,
When thou wound'st a tender heart,
Thy wings being clip'd, and feete hel'd still,
Thy Bow so many could not kill.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.l: It is all one in Venus wanton schoole,
Who highest sits, the wiseman or the foole:

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Accius come in and that quickly; what walking without leaue?

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Silena, I praie you looke homeward, it is a colde aire, and you want your mufler.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: This is pat, if the rest proceed Stellio is like to marrie his daughter to a foole, but a bargen is a bargen.

sp.speaker: Stel
sp.p: This frames to my wish; Memphio is like to marrie a foole to his sonne; Accius tongue shall tie all Memphios land to Silenas dowrie, let his fathers teeth vndoo them if hee can; but heere I see Memphio, I must seeme kind, for in kindnes lies cosnage.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.p:
Wel, here is Stellio, Ile talke of other matters, & flie from the marke I shoot at, lapwing-like flying far from
the place where I nestle. Stellio what make you abroad, I heard you were sicke since our last drinking.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: You see reports are no truths, I heard the like of you, & we are both well. I perceiue sober men tel most lies, for in vino veritas, If they had drunke wine, they would haue tolde the truth.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Our boies wil be sure then neuer to lie, for they are euer swilling of wine, but Stellio I must straine cursie with you, I haue busines, I cannot stay.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: In good time Memphio, for I was about to craue your patience to departe, it stands me vppon. Perhaps moue his patience ere it be long.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Good silly Stel. we must buckle shortly,

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Come Rixula wee haue made thee priuie to the whole packe, there laie downe the packe.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: I beleeue vnlesse it be better handled, wee shall out of doores.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: I care not, Omnem solum forti patria, I can liue in christendome as well as in Kent.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: And Ile sing Patria vbicunque bene, euerie house is my home▪ where I may stanch hunger.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: Nay, if you set all on hazard, though I be a pore wench I am as hardie as you both▪ I cannot speake Latine, but in plaine English if anie thing fall out crosse Ile runne away,

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: He loues thee well that would runne after.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: Why Halfpenie, there's no goose so gray in the lake, that cannot finde a gander for her make.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I loue a nutbrowne lasse, tis good to recreate.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Thou meanest, a browne nut is good to crack.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Why wold it not do thee good to crack such a nut?

sp.speaker: Hal:
sp.p: I feare she is worm-eaten within, she is so moth-eaten without.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: If you take your pleasure of mee, Ile in and tell your practises against your masters.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: In faith soure heart, hee that takes his pleasure on thee is verie pleasurable.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: You meane knauishly, and yet I hope foule water will quench hot fire as soone as fayre.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Well then let fayre wordes coole that cholar, which foule speeches hath kindled, and because we are all in this case, and hope all to haue good fortune, sing a roundelay, and weele helpe, such as thou wast woont when thou beatest hempe.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: It was crabbs she stampt, and stole away one to make her a face.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: I agree in hope that the hempe shall come to your wearing, a halfepenie halter may hang you both, that is, Halfepeny and you may hang in a halter.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Well brought about.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: Twill when tis about your necke.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Nay, now shees in, she will neuer out.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: Nor when your heads are in, as it is lykely, they should not come out. But harken to my song, Cantant.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.l: Then thought I of nothing but hanging,
Then I wish'd for a noyse
On Those hempen strings to be twanging.

sp.speaker: 4 Pag.
sp.l: And fownd no such fidling varlets.

sp.speaker: 4. Pag.
sp.l: May thy hempe choake such singing harlots.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.l: To whit to whoo, the Owle does cry,
Phip, phip, the sparrowes as they fly,
The goose does hisse, the duck cries quack.
A Rope the Parrot, that holds tack.

sp.speaker: 4. Pa.
sp.l: The parrat and the rope be thine.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.l: The hanging yours, but the hempe mine.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Yonder stands the wags, I am come in good time.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: All here before me, you make hast.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: I beleeue to hanging, for I thinke you haue all robd your masters, heres euery man his baggage.

sp.speaker: Hal.
sp.p: That is, we are all with thee, for thou art a verie baggage.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: Hold thy peace, or of mine honesty Ile buy an halfpenie purse with thee.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: In deed thats big inough to put thy honesty in, but come shall we go about the matter?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Now it is come to the pinch my heart pants.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: I for my part am resolute, in vtranque paratus, redie to die or to runne away.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: But heare me, I was troubled with a vile dream, and therefore it is little time spent to let Mother Bomby expound it, she is cunning in all things.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Then will I know my fortune.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: And Ile aske for a siluer spoone which was lost last daie, which I must pay for.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: And Ile know what wil become of our deuices.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Then let vs all go quickly, we must not sleep in this busines, our masters are so watchfull about it.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: Why do you rap so hard at the doore?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Because we would come in.

sp.speaker: Bomb.
sp.p: Nay my house is no Inne.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Crosse your selues, looke how she lookes.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Marke her not, sheele turne vs all to Apes.

sp.speaker: Bom:
sp.p: What would you with me?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: They say you are cunning, & are called the good woman of Rochester.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: If neuer to doo harme be to doo good, I dare saie I am not ill. But whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I had a ill dream, & desire to know the signification.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: Dreames my sonne haue their weight, though they be of a troubled minde, yet are they signes of fortune. Say on.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p:
In the dawning of the day, for about that time by my starting out of my sleepe I found it to bee, mee thought I sawe a stately peece of beefe, with a cape cloke of cabidge, imbrodered with pepper, hauing two honorable pages with hats of mustard on their heades, himselfe in greate pompe sitting vppon a cushion of white Brewish, linde with browne Breade,
me thought being poudred he was much trobled with the salt rume, & therfore there stood by him two great flagons of sacke and beere, the one to drie vp his rume, the other to quench his cholar, I as one enuying his ambition, hungring and thirsting after his honor, began to pull his cushion from vnder him, hoping by that means to giue him a fall, & with putting out my hand awakt, & found nothing in all this dreame about me but the salt rume.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: A dreame for a butcher.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Soft let me end it, then I slumbred againe, & me thought there came in a leg of mutton.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: What all grosse meat, a racke had bene daintie.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Thou foole how could it come in, vnlesse it had bin a leg, me thought his hose were cut & drawen out with parsly, I thrust my hand into my pocket for a knife thinking to hoxe him, and so awakt.

sp.speaker: Bomb.
sp.p: Belyke thou wentst supperlesse to bed.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: So I doo euerie night but sundaies, Prisius hath a weake stomacke, and therefore we must starue.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: Well, take this for answere, though the dream be fantasticall, they that in the morning sleep dream of eating, are in danger of sicknesse, or of beating, or shall heare of a wedding fresh a beating.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: This may be true.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p:
Nay then let me come in with a dreame, short but sweet, that my mouth waters euer since I wakt: Me thought there sate vpon a shelfe three damaske prunes in veluet caps and prest satten gownes like indges, and that there were a whole handfull of curants to be araigned of a riot, because they clunged together in such clusters, twelue raisons of the sunne were impannelled in a Iewry, and as a leafe of whole mase which was bailief was carrying the quest to consult, me thought ther came an angrie cooke, and gelded the Iewry of theyr stones,
and swept both iudges, iurers, rebels and bailiefe into a porredge pot, whereat I being melancholy, fetcht a deepe sigh, that wakt my selfe and my bed fellow.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: This was deuisd not dreamt, and the more foolish being no dreame, for that dreames excuse the fantasticalnesse.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Then aske my bed-felow, you know him, who dreamt that night that the king of diamonds was sicke.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: But thy yeeres and humours pretie child, are subiect to such fansies, which the more vnsensible they seeme, the more fantasticall they are, therefore this dream is easie. To children this is giuen from the Gods to dream of milke, fruit, babies and rods, they betoken nothing but that wantons must haue rods.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Ten to one thy dreame is true, thou wilt bee swinged.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: Nay gammer, I pray you tell me who stole my spoone out of the buttrie.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: Thy spoone is not stolne but mislaide, thou art an ill huswife though a good maid, looke for thy spoon where thou hadst like to be no maide.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: Bodie of me let me fetch the spoone, I remember the place.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Soft swift, the place if it be there now, it will bee there to morrowe.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: I but perchance the spoone will not.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Wert thou once put to it?

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: No sir boy, it was put to me.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: How was it must?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Ile warrant for want of a mist. But whats my fortune▪ mother?

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: Thy father doth liue because he doth die, thou hast spent all thy thrift with a die, and so lyke a begger thou shalt die.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: I woulde haue likte well if all the gerundes had beene there, di, do, and dum, but all in die, thats too deadly.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: My father in deed is a diar, but I haue ben a dicer, but to die a beggar, giue mee leaue not to beleeue Mother Bombie, and yet it may bee, I haue nothing to liue by but knauery, and if the world grow honest welcome beggerie. But what hast thou to say Risio?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Nothing till I see whether all this bee true that she hath sayd.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: I Risio would faine see thee beg.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Nay mother tell vs this, What is all our fortunes, we are about a matter of legerdemaine, howe will it fodge?

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: You shall all thriue like coosners, that is, to bee coosned by coosners: all shall ende well, and you bee found coosners.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Gramercie Mother Bombie, we are all pleasd, if you were for your paines.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: I take no monie, but good wordes, raile not if I tell true, if I doe not reuenge. Farewell. Exit Bom.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Now haue we nothing to doe but to go about this busines, Accius apparell let Candius put on, and I wyll aray Accius with Candius clothes.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Heere is Silenas attire, Linceo put it vpon Liuia, and giue me Liuias for Silena, this done, let Candius & Liuia come foorth, and let Dromio and mee alone for the rest.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: What shall become of Accius and Silena?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Tush, theyr turne shall bee next, all must bee done orderly, lets to it, for nowe it workes.

div.head: Act. 4. Sce. 1.
div.stage: Candius, Liuia, Dromio, Risio, Sperantus, Prisius.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: This attyre is verie fit. But how if this make me a foole and Silena wise, you will then woo mee and wedde her.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Thou knowest that Accius is also a foole, and his rament fits me, so that if apparell be infectious, I am also lyke to be a foole, and hee wist what would be the conclusion, I meruaile

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Here comes our counsellers.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Well sayd, I perceiue turtles flie in couples.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Else how should they couple?

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: So do knaues go double; else how should they be so cunning in doubling.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Bona verba Liuia.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: I vnderstand Latine, that is, Liuia is a good worde.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: No, I byd her vse good wordes.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: And what deeds?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: None but a deed of gift.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: What gift?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Her heart.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Giue mee leaue to pose you though you bee a graduate, for I tell you we in Rochester spurre so many hackneys, that we must needs spurre schollers, for wee take them for hackneys.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: Why so sir boy?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Because I knew two hired for ten grotes a pece to saie seruice on sunday, and thats no more than a post horse from hence to Canterbury.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p:
Hee knowes what hee sayes, for hee once serued
the post-master.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: In deed I thinke hee serued some poast to his master, but come Dromio post me.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: You saie you would haue her heart for a deed.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: If you take her hart for cor, that heart in her bodie, then know this, Molle eiusleuibus, Cor enim inuiolabile telis, A womans heart is thrust through with a feather: if you meane she should giue a heart named Ceruus, then are you worse, for cornua ceruus habet, that is, to haue ones heart growe out at his head, which wyll make one ake at the heart in their bodie.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: I beshrew your hearts, I heare one comming, I know it is my father by his comming.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: What must we doo?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Why as I tolde you, and let me alone with the olde men, fall you to your bridall.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Come neighbor, I perceiue the loue of our children waxeth key colde.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: I thinke it was neuer but luke warme.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Bauins will haue their flashes, and youth their fansies, the one as soone quenched as the other burnt, but who be these?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Here I do plight my faith, taking thee for the staffe of my age, and of my youth my solace.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: And I vow to thee affection which nothing can dissolue, neither the length of time, nor mallice of fortune, not distance of place.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: But when shall we be married?

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: A good question, for that one delay in wedding brings an hundred dangers in the Church, we will not be askt, and a lisence is to chargeable, and to tarrie til to morrow too tedious.

sp.speaker: Dro
sp.p: Theres a girle stands on pricks till she be married.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: To auoid danger, charge, and tediousnesse, let vs now conclude it in the next Church.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: What be these that hasten so to marrie?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Marrie sir, Accius sonne to Memphio, and Silena Stellios daughter.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: I am sorrie neighbour, for our purposes are disappointed.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: You see marriage is destinie, made in heauen, though consumated on earth.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: How like you them, be they not a pretie couple?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Yes God giue them ioye, seeing in spite of our hearts they must ioyne.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: I am sure you are not angrie, seeing things past cannot be recald, and being witnesses to their contract, will be also welwillers to the match.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: For my part I wish them well.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: And I, and since there is no remedie, that I am glad of it.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: But will you neuer heereafter take it in dugeon, but vse them as well as though your selues had made the marriage.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Not, I.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Sir, heres two old men are glad that your loues so long continued, is so happily concluded.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Wee thanke them, and if they will come to Memphios house they shall take parte of a bad dinner. This cottons, and workes like waxe in a sowes eare.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Well, seeing our purposes are preuented, wee must lay other plots, for Liuia shall not haue Candius.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p:
Feare not, for I haue sworne that Candius shall
not haue Liuia. But let not vs fall out because our children fall in.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Wilt thou goe soone to Memphios house?

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: I and if you will let vs, that we may see how the young couple bride it, and so we may teach our owne.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: By this time I am sure, the wagges haue playde their parts, there rests nothing now for vs but to match Accius and Silena

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: It was too good to be true, for we should laugh heartily, and without laughing my spleene would split, but whist here comes the man, Enter Accius .and yonder the maide, let vs stand aside.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: What meanes my father to thrust mee forth in anothers boyes coate? Ile warrant tis to as much purpose as a hem in the forehead.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: There was an auncient prouerbe knockt in the head.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: I am almost come into mine nonage, and yet I neuer was so farre as the prouerbes of this citie.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Theres a quip for the suburbes of Rochester.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Excellently applyed.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Well, though this furniture make mee a sullen dame, yet I hope in mine owne I am no saint.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: A braue fight is lyke to bee betweene a cocke with a long combe, and a hen with a long leg.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Nay her wits are shorter than her legs.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: And his combe longer than his wit.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: I haue yonder vncouered a faire girle, Ile be so bolde as spurre her, what might a bodie call her name?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I cannot help you at this time, I praie you come againe to morrow.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: I marie sir.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: You neede not bee so lustye, you are not so honest.

sp.speaker: Silena.
sp.p: I crie you mercy I tooke you for a ioynd stoole.

sp.speaker: Linceo.
sp.p: Heeres courting for a conduit or a bake-house.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: But what are you for a man? me thinks you loke as pleaseth God.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: What doo you giue me the boots?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Whether will they, here be right coblers cuts.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: I am taken with a fit of loue: Haue you anye minde of marriage?

sp.speaker: Sil:
sp.p: I had thought to haue askt you.

sp.speaker: Acc:
sp.p: Vpon what acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Sil:
sp.p: Who would haue thought it?

sp.speaker: Acc:
sp.p: Much in my gascoins, more in my round hose, all my fathers are as white as daisies, as an egge full of meate.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: And all my fathers plate is made of Crimosin veluet.

sp.speaker: Acc:
sp.p: That braue with bread.

sp.speaker: Halfepenie:
sp.p: These three had wise men to theyr Fathers.

sp.speaker: Lin:
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Because when their bodies were at worke about household stuffe, their mindes were busied about commonwealth matters.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: This is pure lawne: What call you this, a preface to your haire?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Wisely you haue pickt a raison out of a fraile of figges.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: Take it as you list, you are in your owne clothes.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Sauing a reuerence thats a lie, my clothes are better, my father borrowed these.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: Long may hee so doe. I could tell that these are not mine if I would blab it lyke a woman.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I had as liefe you should tell them it snowd.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Come let vs take them off, for we haue had the creame of them.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Ile warrant if this bee the creame, the milke is verie flat, let vs ioyne issue with them.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: To haue such issues of our bodies, is worse than haue an issue in the bodie. God saue you prety mouse.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: You may command and go without.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Theres a glieke for you, let me haue my girde, on thy conscience tell me what tis a clocke?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I cry you mercie I haue kild your cushion.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: I am paid stroke dead in the neast, I am sure this soft youth who is not halfe so wise as you are faire, nor you altogether so faire as he is foolish, will not be so captious.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: Your eloquence passe my recognoscence.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I neuer heard that before, but shal we two make a match betweene you?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Ile know first who was his father.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: My father, what need you to care, I hope he was none of yours.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: A hard question, for it is oddes but one begate them both, hee that cut out the vpper leather, cut out the inner, & so with one awl stitcht two soles together.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: What is she?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Tis Prisius daughter.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: In good time it fodges.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: What is he?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Sperantus sonne.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: So twill cotton.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: Damsell, I pray you how olde are you?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: My sonne would scarce haue askt such a foolish question.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I shall be eighteene next beare-baiting.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: My daughter woulde haue made a wiser aunswere.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: O how fitly this comes of!

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: My father is a scolde, whats yours?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: My heart throbs, I looke him in the face, and yonder I espi Stellio.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: My minde misgiues mee, but whist, yonder is Memphio.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: In faith I perceiue an olde sawe and a rustie, no foole to the olde foole. I praie you wherefore was I thrust out lyke a scar crow in this similitude.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: My sonne and I ashamd, Dromio shall die.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Father are you sneaking behind, I pray you what must I doe next?

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: My daughter, Risio thou hast cosned mee.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Now begins the game.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: How came you hether?

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: Marie by the waie from your house hether?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: How chance in this attire?

sp.speaker: Acc
sp.p: How chance Dromio bid me?

sp.speaker: Memph.
sp.p: Ah thy sonne will bee begd for a concealde foole.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: Will I, I faith sir no.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Wherefore came you hether Silena without leaue?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Because I dyd, and I am heere because I am.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Poore wench, thy wit is improued to the vttermost.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: I, tis an hard matter to haue a wit of the olde rent, euerie one rackes his commons so high.

sp.speaker: Memo.
sp.p: Dromio tolde mee that one should meete Stellios daughter, and courte her in person of my sonne.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Risio tolde me one shoulde meete Memphios sonne, and pleade in place of my daughter.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: But alas I see that my sonne hath met wyth Silena himselfe, and bewraid his folly.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: But I see my daughter hath pratled with Accius, and discouered her simplicitie.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: A braue crie to heare the two olde mules weep ouer the young fooles.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Accius how lykest thou Silena.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: I take her to be pregnant.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Truly his talke is very personable.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Come in girle, this geare must be fetcht about.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Come Accius, let vs go in.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Nay sir there is no harme done, they haue neither bought nor solde, they may be twinnes for theyr wits and yeeres.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: But why diddest thou tell mee it was Prisius sonne?

sp.speaker: Hal.
sp.p: Because I thought thee a foole, to aske who thine owne sonne was.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: And so sir for your daughter, education hath done much, otherwise they are by nature softe wytted inough.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Alas theyr ioyntes are not yet tied, they are not yet come to yeeres and discretion.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: Father, if my handes bee tyed shall I growe wise?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: I and Silena to, if you tie them fast to your tongues.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: You may take your pleasure of my tongue, for it is no mans wife.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Come in Accius.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p: Come in Silena, I wyll talke with Memphios sonne, but as for Risio.

sp.speaker: Memp
sp.p: As for Dromio.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Asse for you all foure,

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: How goes the worlde, now we haue made all sure, Candius and Liuia are maryed, their fathers consenting, yet not knowing.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: We haue flat mard all, Accius and Silena courted one another, their fathers toke them napping, both are ashamd, and you both shall be swingd.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Tush, let vs alone, we will perswade them that all fals out for the best, for if vnderhande this match had bene concluded, they both had ben coosned, and now seeing they finde both to bee fooles, they may be both better aduised. But why is Halfepenle so sad?

sp.speaker: Halfepenie.
sp.p: Because I am sure I shall neuer bee a pennie.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Rather praie there be no fall of monie, for thou wilt then go for a que.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: But did not the two fooles currantly court one another.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p:
Verie good wordes fitly applyed, brought in
in the nicke.

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.p: I arest you.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Me sir, why then didst not bring a stoole wyth thee, that I might sit downe?

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: He arests you at my suite for a horse.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: The more Asse hee, if hee had arested a mare in stead of an horse, it had bin but a slight ouersight, but to arest a man that hath no lykenesse of a horse, is flatte lunasie or alecie.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: Tush, I hired him a horse.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: I sweare then he was well ridden.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: I thinke in two daies he was neuer baited.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Why was it a beare thou ridst on?

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: I meane he neuer gaue him bait.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Why he tooke him for no fish.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: I mistake none of you when I take you for fooles, I say thou neuer gauest my horse meate.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Yes, in foure and fortie houres I am sure he had a bottle of hay as big as his belly.

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.p: Nothing else, thou shouldest haue giuen him prouender.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Why he neuer askt for anie.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: Why, doest thou thinke an horse can speake?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: No, for I spurd him till my heeles akt, and hee sayd neuer a word.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: Well, thou shalt paie sweetly for spoiling him, it was as lustie a nag as anie in Rochester, and one that would stand vpon no ground.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Then is he as good as euer he was, Ile warrant, heele do nothing but lie downe.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: I lent him thee gently.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: And I restored him so gently, that hee neither would cry wyhie nor wag the taile.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: But why didst thou boare him thorough the eares?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: It may be he was set on the pillorie, because hee had not a true pace.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: No, it was for tyring.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: He would neuer tire, it may be he would be so wearie he would go no further, or so.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Yes he was a notable horse for seruice, he wold tyre and retire.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: Doe you thinke Ile be iested out of my horse, Sergeant wreake thy office on him.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Nay stay, let him be baild.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: So he shall when I make him a bargen.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: It was a verie good horse I must needs confesse, and now hearken to his qualities, and haue patience to heare them since I must paie for him: He would stumble three houres in one mile, I had thought I had rode vpon addeces betweene this and Canterburie: if one gaue him water, why he would lie downe & bath himselfe lyke a hauke: if one ranne him, he woulde simper and mump, as though he had gone a wooing to a malt mare at Rochester: hee trotted before and ambled behinde, and was so obedient, that he would doo dutie euerie minute on his knees, as though euerie stone had bin his father.
