sp.speaker: Hack
sp.p: I am sure he had no diseases.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: A little rume or pose, hee lackt nothing but an handkercher.

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.p: Come, what a tale of a horse haue we here, I can not stay, thou must with me to prison.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p:
If thou be a good fellow Hacknyman, take all our foure bondes for the paiment, thou knowest wee are towne borne children, and wil not shrinke the citie for
a pelting iade.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Ile enter into a statute Marchant to see it aunswered. But if thou wilt haue bondes, thou shalt haue a bushell full.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: Alas poore Ant, thou bound in a statute marchant: a browne threed will bind thee fast inough: but if you will be content all foure ioyntly to enter into a bond, I will withdrawe the action.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Yes Ile warrant they will, How say you?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: I yeeld.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: Well call the Scriuener.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Heeres one hard by, Ile call him.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: A scriueners shop hangs to Sergeants mase, like a burre to a freese coate.

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.p: Whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: You must take a note of a bond.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Nay a pint of curtesie puls on a pot of wine, in this Tauerne weele dispatch.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Now if our wits be not in the waine, our knauery shall bee at the full, they will ride them worse than Dromio rid his horse, for if the wine master their wits, you shall see them bleed their follyes.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Euerie foxe to his hole, the houndes are, at hande.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: The Sergeants mase lyes at pawne for the reckning, and he vnder the boord to cast it vp.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: The Scriuener cannot keepe his pen out of the pot, euery goblet is an inkhorne.

sp.speaker: Hal.
sp.p: The hackneyman hee whiskes with his wande, as if the Tauerne were his stable, and all the seruantes his horses, Iost there vp bay Richard, and white loaues are horsebread in his eyes.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: It is well I haue my acquitance, and hee such a bond as shall doo him no more good than the bond of a faggot, our knaueries are now come to the push, and wee must cunningly dispatch all, wee two will goe see howe wee may appease our masters, you two howe you may conceale the late marriage, if all fall out amisse, the worst is beating, if to the best, the worst is lybertie.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Then lettes about it speedely, for so many yrons in the together require a diligent Plummer.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p:
My heart throbbes, my eares tingle, my minde misgiues mee, since I heare such muttering of marry-ages in Rochester, my conscience which these eighteene yeeres hath beene frosen with coniealed guiltynesse, beginnes nowe to thawe in open griefe, but I wil not accuse my selfe til I see more danger, the good olde woman Mother Bombie shall trie her cunning
vpon me, and if I perceiue my case is desperate by her then wyll I rather preuent, although with shame, then report too late, and be inexcusable. God speed good mother.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: Welcome sister.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: I am troubled in the night with dreames, and in the daie with feares, mine estate bare, which I cannot well beare, but my practises deuillish, which I cannot recall, if therefore in these same yeeres there be anie deepe skill, tell what my fortune shall be, and what my fault is.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: In studying to be ouernaturall thou art like to be vnnaturall, and all about a naturall: thou shalt bee eased of a charge if thou thy conscience discharge, and this I commit to thy charge.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Thou hast toucht mee to the quicke mother, I vnderstand thy meaning, and thou well knowest my practise, I will follow thy counsell. But what wyll bee the end?

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: Thou shalt know before this daie end, farewel.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Nowe I perceiue I must either bewraie a mischiefe, or suffer a continual inconuenience, I must hast homewardes, and resolue to make all whole, better a little shame than an infinite griefe, the strangenes will abate the faulte, and the bewraying wipe it cleane away.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p:
Come fellowes, tis almost daie, let vs haue a fit
of mirth at Sperantus doore, and giue a song to the bride.

sp.speaker: Nas.
sp.p: I beleeue they are asleepe, it were pittie to awake them.

sp.speaker: Bed.
sp.p: Twere a shame they shoulde sleepe the first night.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: But who can tell at which house they lie, at Prisius it may be, weele trie both.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Come lets drawe lyke men.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: Now, tune, tune I saie, that boy I thinke will neuer profit in his facultie, he looses his rosen, that his fiddle goes cush, cush, lyke as one should go wetshod, and his mouth so drie, that he hath not spittle for his pinne as I haue.

sp.speaker: Bed.
sp.p: Mary sir you see I go wetshod and dry mouthd, for yet could I neuer get newe shooes or good drinke, rather than Ile leade this life, I throw my fiddle into the leads for a hobler.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: Boy, no more words, theres a time for al things though I say it that should not, I haue bene a minstrell these thirtie yeeres, and tickled more strings than thou hast haires, but yet was neuer so misused.

sp.speaker: Nas.
sp.p: Let vs not brabble but play, to morrow is a new daie.

sp.speaker: Bed.
sp.p: I am sorrie I speake in your cast, what shall wee sing?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: The loue knot, for thats best for a bridall. Sing. God morow fayre bride, and send you ioy of your bridall.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p:
What a mischiefe make the twanglers here? we haue no trenchers to scrape, it makes my teeth on edge to heare such grating. Get you packing, or Ile make you weare double stockes, and yet you shall bee neuer the
warmer.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: We come for good will, to bidd the bride and bride groome, God giue them ioy.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Hers no wedding.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: Yes your sonne and Prisius daughter were maryed, though you seeme strange, yet they repent it not I am sure.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: My sonne villaine, I had rather hee were fairely hanged.

sp.speaker: Nas.
sp.p: So he is sir, you haue your wish.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Here fidlers take this and not a worde, heere is no wedding, it was at Memphios house, yet gramercy, your musicke though it mist the house hit the minde, we were a preparing our wedding geare.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: I crie you mercie sir, I thinke it was Memphios sonne that was married.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: O ho the case is altered, go thether then and be haltered for me.

sp.speaker: Nas.
sp.p: Whats the almes?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: An Angell.

sp.speaker: Bed.
sp.p: Ile warrant thers some worke towards, ten shillings is money in master Maiors purse.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: Let vs to Memphios and share equally, when we haue done all thou shalt haue new shooes.

sp.speaker: Bed.
sp.p: I such as they cry at the Sizes, a marke in issues, and marke in issues, and yet I neuer sawe so much leather as would peece ones shooes.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: No more, thers the mony.

sp.speaker: Bed.
sp.p: A good handsell, and I thinke the maidenhead of your liberalitie.

sp.speaker: Nas.
sp.p: Come heres the house, what shall we sing?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p:
You know Memphio is verie rich and wise, and
therefore let vs strike the gentle stroke, and sing a catch.

sp.speaker: All 3.
sp.l: THe Bride this Night can catch no cold,
No cold, the Bridegroome's yong, not old,
Like Iuie he her fast does hold,

sp.speaker: All 3.
sp.l: Then let them alone, They know what they doe.
At laugh and lie downe, if they play,
What Asse against the sport can bray?
Such Tick-tacke has held many a day,

sp.speaker: All 3.
sp.l: Then let them alone, They know what they doe,

sp.speaker: Nas.
sp.p: God morrowe mistres bride and sende you a huddle.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: What crouding knaues haue we there, case vp your fiddles, or the cunstable shall cage you vppe. What bride talke you of?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: Heres a wedding in Rochester, and twas tolde me first that Sperantus son had married Prisius daughter, we were there, and they sent vs to your worshippe, saying your son was matched with Stellios daughter.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Hath Sperantus that churle nothing to doe but mocke his neighbours, Ile bee euen with him, and get you gone, or I sweare by the roodes bodie Ile laye you by the heeles.

sp.speaker: Nas.
sp.p: Sing a catch, heres a faire catch in deed, sing til we catch colde on our feet, and bee cald knaue tyll our eares glowe on our heades, your worshippe is wise sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Dromio shake off a whole kennel of officers, to punish these iarring rogues, Ile teach them to stretch theyr dried sheepes guts at my doore, and to mock one that stands to be maior.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: I had thought they had beene sticking of pigs, I heard such a squeaking, I go sir.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: Let vs be packing.

sp.speaker: Nas.
sp.p: Where is my scabbarde, euerye one sheath his science.

sp.speaker: Bed.
sp.p: A bots on the shoemaker that made this boote for my fiddle, tis too straight.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: No more wordes, twill bee thought they were the foure waites, and let them wring, as or the wagges that set vs on worke, wele talke with them.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: They be gone sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: If they had stayed, the stockes shoulde haue staied them. But sirra, what shall we now doo?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: As I aduised you make a match, for better one house be cumbered with two fooles than two.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Tis true, for it beeing bruted that eache of vs haue a foole, who will tender marriage to anie of them that is wise, besides fooles are fortunate, fooles are faire, fooles are honest.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: I sir, and more than that, fooles are not wise: a wise man is melancholy for moone-shine in the water, carefull building castles in the ayre, & commonly hath a foole to his heyre.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: But what sayest thou to thy dames chasing?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Nothing but all her dishes are chasing dishes.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: I would her tongue were in thy belly.

sp.speaker: Dro,
sp.p: I had as liefe haue a rawe neates tongue in my stomacke.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Marie if the clapper hang within an inch of my heart, that makes mine eares burne a quarter of a mile off. Do you not thinke it would beate my heart blacke and blew?

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Well patience is a vertue, but pinching is worse than any vice, I wil breake this matter to Stellio, and if he be willing, this day shall be their wedding.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Then this day shall be my libertie.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: I if Stellios daughter had beene wise, and by my meanes cosned of a foole.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Then sir Ile reuolt, and dash out the braines of your deuises.

sp.speaker: Memph.
sp.p: Rather thou shalt be free.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Boy, this smoake is a token of some fire, I lyke not the lucke of it. Wherefore should these minstrelles dreame of a marryage?

sp.speaker: Hal.
sp.p: Alas sir they rustle into euery place, giue credit to no such wordes.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: I will to Prisius, I cannot be quiet, and in good time I meet him, God morow neighbor.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I cast the morrow in thy fate, & bid good night to all neighborhood.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: This is your olde tricke, to pick ones purse & then to picke quarrels, I tell thee, I had rather thou shouldest rob my chest than imbesell my sonne.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Thy sonne, my daughter is seduced, for I heare say she is marryed, and our boyes can tell. How sayest thou, tell the truth or Ile grinde thee to pouder in my mill, Be they marryed?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: True it is they were both in a church.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: That no fault, the place is holy.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: And there was with them a priest.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Why what place fitter for a priest than a church?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: And they tooke one another by the hand.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Trush, thats but common curtesie.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: And the priest spake many kinde wordes.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: That shewed hee was no dumbe minister. But what sayde they, diddest thou heare anie wordes betweene them?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Faith there was a bargaine during life, and the clocke cryed, God giue them ioy.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Villaine they be marryed.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Nay I thinke not so.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Yes, yes, God giue you ioy is a binder, Ile quickly be resolud, Candius come forth.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: And Ile be put out of doubt. Liuia come forth.

sp.speaker: Spe:
sp.p: The micher hangs downe his head.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: The baggage begins to blush.

sp.speaker: Half:
sp.p: Now begins the game.

sp.speaker: Lin:
sp.p: I beleeue it will be no game for vs.

sp.speaker: Spe:
sp.p: Are you marryed yong master?

sp.speaker: Can:
sp.p: I cannot denie it, it was done so lately.

sp.speaker: Spe:
sp.p: But thou shalt repent, it was done so soone.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Then tis bootlesse to aske you Liuia.

sp.speaker: Liu:
sp.p: I, and needlesse to be angrie.

sp.speaker: Pri:
sp.p: It shall passe anger, thou shalt finde it rage.

sp.speaker: Liu:
sp.p: You gaue your consent.

sp.speaker: Pri:
sp.p: Impudent giglot, was it not inough to abuse me but also to belie me?

sp.speaker: Can:
sp.p: You sir agreed to this match.

sp.speaker: Spe:
sp.p: Thou brasen face boy, thinkest thou by learning to persuade me to that which thou speakest. Where did I consent, when, what witnes?

sp.speaker: Can:
sp.p: In this place yesterday before Dromio & Risio.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I remember we heard a contract between Memphios sonne and Stellios daughter, and that our good wils being asked which needed not, wee gaue them, which booted not.

sp.speaker: Can:
sp.p: Twas but the apparell of Accius and Silena, we were the persons.

sp.speaker: Pri:
sp.p: O villany not to be borne, Wast thou priuie to this practise?

sp.speaker: Lin:
sp.p: In a manner.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Ile pay thee after a manner.

sp.speaker: Spe:
sp.p: And you oatemeale groate, you were acquainted with this plot.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Accessarie as it were.

sp.speaker: Spe:
sp.p: Thou shalt be punished as principal: here comes Memphio and Stellio, they belike were priuie, and all theyr heads were layde together to grieue our heartes.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Come Stellio, the assurance may be made to morrow, aud our children assured to day.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Let the conueyance runne as we agreed.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: You conuey cleanely in deede, if coosnage bee cleane dealing, for in the apparell of your children you haue conuaide a match betweene ours, which grieues vs not a little.

sp.speaker: Mem:
sp.p: Nay in the apparel of your children you haue discouerd the folly of ours, which shames vs ouermuch

sp.speaker: Stel:
sp.p: But tis no matter, though they bee fooles they are no beggers.

sp.speaker: Spe:
sp.p: And thogh ours be disobedient, they be no fools.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: So now they tune theyr pipes.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: You shall heare sweet musicke betweene a hoarse rauen and a schritch owle.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Neighbours, let vs not vary, our boyes haue playd theyr cheating partes, I suspected no lesse at the Tauerne, where foure foure knaues met together.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: If it were knauery for foure to meet in a Tauerne, your wor. wot well there were other foure.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: This villaine cals vs knaues by craft.

sp.speaker: Lin:
sp.p: Nay truly I dare sweare hee vsed no crafte, but meanes plainly.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: This is worse, come Half. tel truth & scape the rod.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: As good honfesse heere beeing trust, as at home with my hose about my heeles.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Nay Ile tell thee, for twill neuer become the to vtter it.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Well out with it.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Memphio had a foole to his sonne which Stellio knew not, Stellio a foole to his daughter vnknowen to Memphio; to coosen eache other they dealte with theyr boyes for a match; we met with Lincio and Halfepenie, who told the loue betweene their masters children, the youth deeply In loue, the fathers vnwitting to consent.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Ile take the tale by the end; then wee foure met, which argued we were no mountaines, and in a tauern we met, which argued we were mortall, and euery one in his wine told his dayes worke, which was a signe we forgot not our busines, and seeing all our masters troubled with deuises, we determined a little to trouble the water before they dronke, so that in the attire of your children our masters wise children bewrayed theyr good natures, and in the garments of our masters children yours made a marriage; this all stoode vppon vs poore children and your yong children, to shewe that olde folkes may be ouertaken by children.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Heres a children in deed, Ile neuer forget it.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: I will, Accius come forth.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: I forgiue all, Silena come forth.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Neighbor, these things cannot be recald, therefore as good consent, seeing in all our purposes also we mist the marke, for they two will match their children.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Well of that more anone, not so sodainely least our vngratious youths thinke we dare do no other, but in truth their loues stirres vp nature in me.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Come Accius thou must be marryed to Silenena. How art thou minded?

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: What for euer & Mem. i Accius, what els?

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: I shall neuer be able to abide it, it will be so tedious.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Silena thou must be betrothed to Accius, & loue him for thy husband.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I had as liefe haue one of clouts.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Why Silena?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Why looke how he lookes.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: If you will not another will.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I thanke you for mine olde cap.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: And if you be so lustie lend me two shillings.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: We are happie, we mist the foolish match.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Come you shall presently be contracted.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Contract their wits no more, they bee shronke close already.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: Well father heeres my hande, strike the bargaine.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Must he lie with me?

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: No Silena, lie by thee.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: I shall giue her the humble bees kisse.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: I forbid the banes.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: What doest thou thinke them rattes, and fearest they shall be poisoned?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: You Vicinia, wherefore?

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Hearken, about eighteene yeeres agoe I must thee a sonne Memphio, and thee a daughter Stellio.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p:
I had at that time two children of mine owne, and being poore, thought it better to change them than kill them, I imagined if by deuice I coulde thrust my children into your houses, they should be wel brought vp in their youth, and wisely prouided for in their age,
nature wrought with me, and when they were weaned I sent home mine in sted of yours, which hetherto you haue kept tenderly as yours: growing in yeres I founde the children I kept at home to loue dearely, at first lyke brother and sister, which I reioyced at, but at length too forward in affection, which although inwardly I could not mislike, yet openly I seemed to disallowe: they increased in their louing humours, I ceased not to chastise them for theyr loose demeanors, at last it came to my eares, that my sonne that was out with Memphio was a foole, that my daughter with Stellio was also vnwise, and yet beeing brother and sister, there was a match in hammering betwixt them.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: What monstrous tale is this?

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: And I am sure incredible.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Let her end her discourse.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: Ile neuer beleeue it.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Holde thy peace.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: My verie bowels earned within me, that I shuld be author of such vilde incest, an hinderance to lawfull loue, I went to the good olde woman Mother Bombie to knowe the euent of this practise, who tolde mee this day I might preuent the danger, and vpon submission escape the punishment, hether I am come to claime my children, though both fooles, and to deliuer yours both louing.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Is this possible, how shall we beleeue it?

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: I cannot sinke into my head.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p:
This triall cannot faile, your sonne Memphio had a moale vnder his care, I framed one vnder my childes care by arte, you shall see it taken away with the iuyce of mandrage, beholde nowe for your sonnes, no hearbe can vndo that nature hath done. Your daughter
Stellio hath on her wrist a moale, which I counterfeted on my daughters arme, & that shall you see taken away as the other. Thus you see I doe not dissemble, hoping you will pardon me, as I haue pittied them.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: This is my sonne, O fortunate Memphio!

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: This is my daughter, more than thrice happie Stellio?

sp.speaker: Maest.
sp.p: How happie is Maestius thou blessed Serena, that being neither children to poore parents, nor brother and sister by nature, may inioye their loue by consent of parents and nature.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: Solt, Ile not swap my father for all this.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: What do you thinke Ile be cosned of my father, me thinkes I should not, Mother Bombie tolde me my father knew mee not, my mother bore mee not, falsely bred, truly begot, a bots on Mother Bomby.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Mother Bombie tolde vs we should be founde coosners, and in the end be cosned by cosners, welfare Mother Bomby.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: I heard Mother Bomby saie that thou shalt die a beggar, beware of Mother Bomby.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Why haue you all bene with Mother Bomby?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: All, and as farre as I can see foretolde all.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: In deed she is cunning and wise, neuer doing harme, but still practising good, seeing these things fall out thus, are you content Stellio the match goe forward.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: I, with double ioye, hauing found for a foole a wise maide, and finding betweene them both exceeding loue.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Then to end alliars, our childrens matches shall stand with our good liking, Liuia inioy Candius.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Candius inioy Liuia.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p:
How shall we recompence fortune, that to our
loues hath added our parents good wills?

sp.speaker: Maest.
sp.p: How shall wee requite fortune, that to our loues hath added lawfulnesse, and to our poore estate competent liuing?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Vicinia thy fact is pardoned, though the law would see it punisht, wee be content to keepe Silena in the house with the new married couple.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: And I doo maintaine Accius in our house.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Come my children, though fortune hath not prouided you landes, yet you see you are not destitute of friends, I shall be eased of a charge both in purse and conscience, in conscience, haue reuealed my lewd practise, in purse, hauing you kept of almes.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: Come if you bee my sister its the better for you.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Come brother, me thinkes its better than it was, I should haue beene but a balde bride, Ile eate as much pie as if I had bene marryed.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Lets also forgiue the knauerie of our boyes since all turnes to our good haps.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Agreed, all are pleased nowe the boyes are vnpunisht.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: Nay softe, take vs with you, and seeke redresse for our wrongs, or weele complaine to the Maior.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p:
I arested Memphios boye for an horse after much mocking, at the request of his fellowe wagges, I was content to take a bonde ioyntlye of them all, they had me into a tauerne, there they made me, the Scriuener, and the Sergeant dronke, paunde his mase for the wine, and seald mee an obligation nothing to the purpose,
I pray you reade it.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: What wags be these? Why by this bond you can demand nothing, and thinges done in drinke, may be repented in sobernes, but not remedyed.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Sir, I haue his acquittaunce, lette him sue his bonde.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: Ile crie quittance with thee.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: And I, or it shall cost me the laying on freelie of my mase.

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.p: And Ile giue thee such a dash with a pen as shall cost thee many a pound, wish such a Nouerimt as cheap side can shew none such.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Doe your worst, our knaueries will reuenge it vpon your childrens children.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Thou boy, we wil paie the hire of the horse, be not angrie, the boyes haue bene in a merrie cosning vaine, for they haue serued their masters of the same sorte, but all must be forgotten, now all are content but the poore fidlers, they shal be sent for to the marriage & haue double fees.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: You need no more send for a fidler to a feast, than a begger to a fayre.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: This daie we will feast at my house.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: To morrow at mine.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: The next day at mine.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Then at mine the last day, & euen so spend this weeke in good cheere.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Then we were best be going whilest euery one is pleasd, and yet these couples are not fully pleasde, till the priest haue done his worst.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Come Sergeant weele tosse it this weeke, and make thy mase arest a boild capon.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
No more words at the wedding, if the maior shuld
know it, I were in danger of mine office.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Then take heed how on such as we are, you shew a cast of your office.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: If you mace vs, weele pepper you.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: Come sister, the best is, we shall haue good chere these foure dayes.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: And be fooles for euer.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Thats none of our vpseckings.
